pullRequest.body:
From GrowthInGroups (LeanCamCombi)

Co-authored-by: Andrew Yang


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [bcf5783b4d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20070/commits/bcf5783b4d596a0f114dbff7e837484e1e243b0e)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +31.47% | `Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.Algebra` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.Algebra | 1036 | 1362 | +326 (+31.47%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.RingHom.FinitePresentation`|3|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.Free`|106|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.Finiteness`|238|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Localization.Algebra`|326|

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ isLocalization`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
@faenuccio, are +326 imports really worth it?
The corresponding result for `MvPolynomial` lives in `RingTheory.MvPolynomial.Localization`. Should I create a new file `RingTheory.Polynomial.Localization`? What do you think, @faenuccio ?

Yes, well spotted.

Feel free to push anything to this PR so long as you can keep #20303 compiling!

I think the title should say "... is the polynomial ring over the localization of `R` at `S`"?
I'm considering using [polyEquivTensor](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/PolynomialAlgebra.html#polyEquivTensor), [isLocalizedModule_iff_isBaseChange](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Localization/BaseChange.html#isLocalizedModule_iff_isBaseChange) and [isLocalizedModule_iff_isLocalization](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/LocalizedModule/IsLocalization.html#isLocalizedModule_iff_isLocalization) to golf the proof, and also generalize to CommSemirings.

I think the title should say "... is the polynomial ring over the localization of `R` at `S`"?
I'm considering using [polyEquivTensor](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/PolynomialAlgebra.html#polyEquivTensor), [isLocalizedModule_iff_isBaseChange](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Localization/BaseChange.html#isLocalizedModule_iff_isBaseChange) and [isLocalizedModule_iff_isLocalization](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/LocalizedModule/IsLocalization.html#isLocalizedModule_iff_isLocalization) to golf the proof, and also generalize to CommSemirings.

```suggestion
  · intro x y e
```
Isn't this precisely the use case of `ìntros`? I don't really see the point of changing here

Well, my take on `intros` is that it is useful used with anonymous hypotesis, but with named ones it has the same effect as `intro` now (I had this discussion with Kyle in https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/270676-lean4/topic/intros.20hover). Of course it is a minor point, but since `intro` works, I'd be happier to use this so that newcomers (or Lean3 nostalgics) don't think that the `s` is really needed. And one character less, an incredible gain
At this point, I would rather wait for the `intro ..` syntax to replace `intros` rather than thinking about the color of the bikeshed myself
I wonder if this is the correct file for this lemma, it seems to me that it has nothing to do with Integral elements. Perhaps in Localization.Algebra?
The proof uses `IsLocalization.integerNormalization_spec`, which is proved in this file, so I think it's the right spot?

Yes, I agree, but in a sense this is an accident: see Bourbaki, Alg. Comm, Chap III, § 2, no. 8 for the proof that localization commutes more generally with symmetric algebras (over any ring, no need for it to be commutative btw), and univariate polynomials are a special case. Now, I am of course not arguing that we should first define symmetric algebras and prove the result in that generality, it is great to have this result now. But I feel that from a math point of view this result is unrelated to integrality and should be in its "moral" home, even if it is not yet clear why it is there. Can't you simply import `isLocalization.integerNormalization_spec` in `Localization.Algebra`?

What is going on here mathematically? You're comparing two polynomials that you want to show equal, why do you care about the support? I am asking mainly to see how much pain would be to generalize this to power series and/or MVpolynomials.

Should work just the same for power series and mv polynomials, yes. We have a sequence `c` such that `c n * x.coeff n = c n * y.coeff n` for all `n`. Now we want to find a single `c'` such that `c * x = c * y`. Answer: take a common multiple of all the `c n` for which either `x.coeff n` or `y.coeff n` is non-zero.
Since this is not the "usual math proof" (to my knowledge), would you mind half-a-line of doc in this proof to make this explicit? I think it can be interesting while inspecting it later on.

pullRequest.title: feat: the localization of `R[X]` at `S` is the polynomial ring over the localization of `R` at `S`

source.title: feat: split a set in the prime spectrum of `R[X]` into its localization at `c : R` and quotient by `c` parts

nodes.body: The corresponding result for `MvPolynomial` lives in `RingTheory.MvPolynomial.Localization`. Should I create a new file `RingTheory.Polynomial.Localization`? What do you think, @faenuccio ?
